Indian Cinema has seen quite a lot of films set in the colonial milieu espousing the freedom struggle, but what sets apart Sardar Udham from the rest is its interesting treatment of the revenge drama trope complimented well by the rich production design, staying clear of the usual stereotypes with dramatization and expressional typecasting of Western artistes.Set in the backdrop of the Jallianwala Bagh massacre, the film explores the motivations for the Indian Revolutionary Udham Singh for deciding to avenge the act committed during the British rule. At its heart, the film wishes for the audience to empathize with the victims and realize the value of the revenge that was taken, as does many others. Munich comes to mind immediately that handled the arc so very well and succeeded in creating the kind of impact. This one too does, but rather than setting the anger seethe in the audience in the initial moments to be pacified later through revenge, the screenplay of Sardhar Udham takes us on a deep-dive into the psyche of protagonist, the act of revenge and his modus operandi before unleashing the bloody act bare on the screen. The result is that it leaves a larger impact on us that lingers for a long time even after the movie is over.The film also deserves appreciation for not being too preachy and resists from the popular temptation to drive home the communist doctrines of the protagonist outside the context of freedom struggle. There is just one instance of a clash he has with his supervisor that comes close, but largely the film stays clear of influencing political opinions and staying matter of fact to the characters' stances. Melodrama too is largely adequate and doesn't go overboard except towards the last portion of the movie wherein a little sense of repetition creeps in, though not to the extent of diluting the impact. What is more astounding about the movie is how well the narration travels back and forth time in sync with that Udham undergoes during the investigation, without them necessarily being a narration from the characters themselves. The supporting characters - from the one who plays Bhagat Singh, Scotland Yard policemen, the communist leader, Udham's accomplices, his love interest to the villains of the act, all get utilized just to play their parts, being significant without being loud.As far as performances go, Vicky Kaushal hits it out of the park. And so do every other supporting artiste, including the non-Indian performers, whose expressions have remained more native than artificial as it usually has been in other Indian period dramas. Technically, the production value for bringing out the setting for this historical drama is tremendous and never really gets itself self-promoted to shout its significance. The Britain of 1920's has never been shown with such authenticity in Indian cinema before, as I recollect. Cinematography too was exquisite, however felt the hand-held movements were over done in some places, specifically the interrogation scenes. Editing played a significant part in elevating the screenplay travels during the narration and as far as the drag in the last section goes, the blame doesn't lie as much in editing as it does on the deliberate intention in the writing.Overall - one of the finest movies to come out in recent times. Go watch it.

reviews.review_title: I once said, "Bollywood could never make a historical movie as impactful as 'Schindler's List'.". Shoojit proved me wrong.
reviews.content: Let me begin by telling you that I saw "Madras Cafe" few years back and never thought that Shoojit could make a better movie than that, it seemed THAT perfect to me. However, I was wronged, when saw "Sardar Udham (2021)" on Amazon Prime, and was struck deeply by the silent-to-the-world aftermath of Jallianwala Bagh Massacre, which is rarely discussed in History Books but shown loud and clear in the movie. I can't do justice in this small review with limited words about how perfectly the time period between 1920s to 1940s is shown in the movie. The sets, backgrounds, incidents, screenplay, dialogue and costumes are so well researched (this thing is missed in most bollywood historical movies), I praise everyone who were behind it. Vicky Kaushal gives his 100% and successfully justifies great "Shaheed Udham Singh" ji. Other than him, rest of the cast are also impactful.Now, coming to the core story, the best thing about "Sardar Udham" is that it not just tells you a story and gives you a 'history lesson', but makes you ask questions about everyone's actions involved, and through its non-linear story, gives you answers of them one by one. This makes it A MUST WATCH!Lastly, I want to say that this movie matches the level of Spielberg's Schindler's List, which is hardest to match (also, which is my favorite movie). Hats off to Shoojit and team!

reviews.review_title: Shoojit Sircar's brilliant cinema makes this worth watching!
reviews.content: Have grown up reading about the Jallianwala Bagh massacre in school and hearing the infamous mention of this piece of history, in many a patriotic film, but never ever, I imagined the brutality of the bloodbath, the massacre, so vividly and in such a horrific way, as it is shown in Shoojit Sircar's Sardar Udham. It makes you sit up and realize and understand the enormity of all that happened on a dreadful day. The 15-20 minutes of the Jallianwala bagh sequence is disturbing, to say the least, with thousands of bodies piled up, blood everywhere, people moaning in pain, and Sardar Udham shouting in angst - koi Zinda hai (is anyone alive)? Is enough to send chills down the spine and give you goosebumps. That one scene will definitely stay with you for a long time, leaving you teary-eyed and tugging at your heartstrings! It makes you feel helpless, fills you up with rage, makes you want to go down on your knees and pray for the people suffering and empathize with them!No doubt, there have been many patriotic films that leave a mark on you but somehow I felt, one way or the other, it always got bogged down by the eternal Bollywood-ism of loud music or unnecessary dialogues, trying to make the film or the protagonist larger than life, but Sardar Udham strictly refrains from toeing the treaded Bollywood line! It is unrelenting, non-apologetic in its premise of showing the true events, as is, without taking too many cinematic liberties. Shoojit Sircar's grip on the screenplay is so taut, that even at 2.45 hours of screentime, you cannot take yourself away from it all. Helping him in this is the wonderful cinematography of Avik Mukhopadhyay, which sets the tone for the film. Be it the misty Punjab farms, the snowcapped Russia, the bloodbath at the JB, everything lends authenticity to the plot.Vicky Kaushal's given a stellar performance from being a young boy unable to fathom what's going on to becoming totally stoic after seeing so many deaths to being totally focussed single-mindedly about avenging the JB massacre, in other words, he need not even ask - how's the josh? He practically lives Sardar Udham and fills you up with josh with his measured performance. Amol Parashar, Banita Sandhu, and Kristy Everton make an impression too, even though their roles being small.As said earlier too, Sardar Udham does not tread the familiar line, hence you do not have any gora talking in anglicized Hindi and all, (thank God and Shoojit) and thus you have Shaun Scott and Stephen Hogan again bringing authenticity to the table.Sardar Udham has a lot to offer in terms of the narrative, the cinematography, the action and it impacts you deeply and leaves you in a contemplative mood, long after you finish watching the movie. As Sardar Udham says "probably for you JB is a footnote, written somewhere in fine print" it was the same for me too until Shoojit Sircar decided to bring it on the canvas in such an explicit way, that now am able to comprehend and acknowledge the tragedy that was Jallianwala bagh in all its brutality!Sardar Udham is one movie that you are not going to forget in a hurry! Go for it!

reviews.review_title: This is how you make a biopic

"Revolution is an inalienable right of mankind. Freedom is an imperishable birthright of all" - Bhagat SinghWow! What an incredible piece of Cinema I have just been a witness of! I'm truly captivated by Sircar's direction and the way he addressed such a heroic act of patriotism. And I can't convey enough appreciation for representing such a fairly unknown story of the Martyr, Udham Singh; who against all the odds made the impossible. He shook the British empire to its core and sent out a decisive statement against their heinous colonialism.From a technical stance alone, I must admit, this was something very special! I had never seen a historical drama on such an enormous scale before. From the detailed set designs to the astounding Cinematography, the commendable art direction to the world-building; it has every right to be considered as a landmark in Indian filmography. Trust me, supervising any sets with that many people and intricacies; it's easier said than done. And this gets even more fascinating when you consider the restricted expenditures!Likewise, the performances leave quite an impression. Amongst the entire cast, Vicky Kaushal's act indisputably draws our attention the most. Particularly, towards the end. Where, in my opinion; he gives his absolute best. Speaking of the rest of the ensemble, I was amazed to observe such a capable group of foreign nationals playing their roles with utmost affection and integrity!My only criticisms are in regards to the comparatively long-winded screenplay and its Non-linear structure. Don't get me wrong, I'm all up for Non-linear storytelling, but I'm not sure whether it was an absolute necessity in this case.Even though I gotta say, that whole Jallianwala Bagh massacre sequence is no less than a cinematic brilliance. No matter, how tough you deem yourself to be, remember the words; it's gonna break your heart. If it was up to me, I would have probably inaugurated the film with this portion rather than placing it near the climax. That way, I guess the impact would have been far greater.Lastly, I just wanna thank all the people who have contributed to such an ambitious endeavour and I wanna give my regards to Mr Shoojit Sircar as he's done plentiful to denote the atrocities of British Imperialism. Innumerable manslaughters, abscondings, tortures; the British without any question, shares a dark & sinful past with our country and its people.My heartiest admiration goes to all the martyrs and their families who sacrificed everything just to break the shackles and to get our much-awaited Sovereignty & Freedom. And most importantly they did all that while being unified, irrespective of class, religion or Identity.

reviews.review_title: Let the world know, Udham Singh was a revolutionary
reviews.content: "Let the world know, I was a revolutionary"In the recent years we experienced numerous movies, either some over dramatic biopic or extreme patriotic melodrama, are coming out with the same silly prototype to capture a certain portion of audience. Some are decent, some are below average & most of them are unbearable with otherworldly odd vfx and whatsapp status special love songs no one asked for! In this suffocating condition of biographical movies, to break the sinister prototype skeleton, a cinematic revolution was much needed; Shoojit Sircar brought it with a masterstroke named Sardar Udham!Inspite of the promise shown by the film, I didn't expect that it can avoid the typical bollywood biography making formula completely and masterfully! I am not sure what to say and what not about this technically supreme work. From the colour and cinematography to the recreation of historically accurate scenes; from the extraordinary score to the blazing screenplay; everything was so technical that it demands a separate writing.There is no need of any forcibly induced emotional scenes or jingoistic dialogues when you have a strong story in hand and technical men at office. In this type of work, the rawness should be evident to justify the actions. Director did exactly the same. He kept the raw tone intact and treated it with a no nonsense approach.The movie did exceptionally well with some dicision making. Use of original languages and not hindi in abnormal accent was one of the main reason why the movie feels so original. The story telling technique was also authentic. Special mention to the Jallianwala Bagh massacre recreation; it was so detailed, raw and moving that we can feel ourselves there!Vicky Kaushal added another feather in his cap delivering a composed, mature yet breathtaking performance as Udham Singh. Supporting casts were brilliant and apt. The unbiased development of characters was also superb. Actually there were hardly anything to complain about in this masterfully crafted movie.Sircar's Sardar Udham is the only biographical work coming out from Bollywood in recent years, which is able to break the rusty prototype and create a benchmark which will surely bring a wave of making serious movies devoid off the business model approach! Remarkable..

The name, 'Jallianwala Bagh' might be a 'TONGUE TWISTER'' to few of the modern day politicians to spell. But the MASSACRE that happened there in 1919 left an irreparable SCAR on the face of British Rule and gave a TANGO TWIST to the India's freedom fight across the country.The DYRE and DWYRE combo choose to create DIRE situation at Amritsar which resulted in a relentless firing on a HARMLESS protestors, in which thousands of ARMLESS people DIED and many injuered. However, there was one man who survived during this brutal massacre, decided to TEACH BACK the LESSON in the same language during a felicitation SESSION by shooting DWYRE. This is the story of SARDAR UDHAM SINGH and it took him 21 years to take the REVENGE. However, as a typical Indian, UDHAM had checked whether he holds any regret for being responsible for the massacre and takes this step only after knowing that Dwyre is unapologetic about that incident.The movie at times looks like a documentary. But it is powerful enough to give the feeling of "not so nice" experiences of the past. Probably instead of OTT, if this movie would have been released in Theatres, it would have been more impactful on the audience. Nevertheless, the last one hour makes you angry and the replica of the incident shown will boil your BLOOD as you see BLOOD Bath and DEAD BODIES Path.Vicky Kaushal is at his Best. He smiles (apart from the Romantic scenes) only once when he says, "when I go to heaven, I want to ask my teacher WHETHER I gave my YOUTH any meaning or let it to WITHER". He has not just acted but lived through the character of UDHAM. Amol Parashar as Bhagath Singh too impresses during his short appearence. Shoojit Sircar has once again proves his brilliance in showcasing the subject by giving his midas touch. The early 19th century has been replicated with all the props and costumes to make it look authentic. Shantanu Moitra uses silence at many places to bring the emotions which could have been spoiled otherwise with some background music. One of the UNSUNG Hero's UNTOLD story is presented to understand what all sacrifices it took to get us the Independence when someone recently heard saying British were respectful to Indians during their rule.Last Line:The Detective talks lightly on Bhagath Singh. reviews.review_title: Fascinating cinematography, gripping storyline, phenomenal acting

You see, World War 2 is one of the major reason behind India's independence but our historians and filmmakers have always overlooked this fact. You gotta know that British saw it coming back what they did to India. In this movie there is a quote to explain this- "Germany calling. The sun finally seems to setting at British Empire. Like an elephant, Indians never forget their enemies" and the next two scenes when Udham Singh questions the Law twice, once in Courtroom before Judge and once during investigation in front of detective. Do you remember any Bollywood Film going in such details about ideology and morals? Leave that topic for further arguments later.So, overall Sardar Udham is quite a break from commercial potboilers and there are many reasons to make it a Must See in your watchlist as a true quality cinema lover. However, couple of flaws needs to be bashed equally as i praised good things. The film starts very slow, it looks scattered and irrelevant sometimes but maybe that's because the story of Udham never has enough documents and events available in public domain. I won't say much about acting and other aspects as said in the beginning but for Vicky Kaushal I say one thing that he has completely surrendered himself to director's uncompromised vision. I won't be surprised to see him taking a bunch of trophies home after the award ceremonies next year. Shoojit Sir, you have attempted something revolutionary and respect you for that. Nevertheless, i still say it could have been little better or a certain Classic. It misses that Mark by few inches though. Rest, highly recommended. reviews.review_title: A history told beyond numbers, names and dates. Fully unadulterated
reviews.content: The movie is perfect. For the impatient ones watching the movie, it will tell you the story of the killing of Michael O Dwyer in first 30 mins. But at this point the movie starts to raise doubts, is this killing, is just a revenge, or an act of terror or a revolution? Right at this point some background of Udham Singh, working with Bhagat Singh is shown where Bhagat Singh defines what's a revolution. Udham Singh is arrested on the spot and a formal investigation starts in the movie, which shows more background on the events that lead from Jallianwala Bagh Massacre till this day.The movie shows how Udham Singh, having multiple chances to kill Michael O Dwyer, won't kill him just like that. He tries to understand O Dwyer's views, on how he felt about the Jallianwala Bagh, was it justified, with having a concealed gun in his hand and Dwyer casually drinking. The movie drop hints on PTSD faced by Udham Singh adds another dimension to the tragedy of the survivors.The best part of the movie is the sequence in which events are shown. It does shows the actual brutality but at the very end of the movie so as to not overwhelm the viewers with anger and anguish right from the beginning and give viewers a chance to see the real Udham Singh.The movie makes perfect sense in today's world, where mob-lynchings are getting comfortably justified rather than considering it as an act of terror. There is an urgent need of publicising adopting the right ideology of Bhagat Singh, and letting the people decide if there is unnecessary fear being instigated in the society by some people who then take advantage of this fear Or if the society is actually inspired.Thanks.

Vicky Kaushal is at the right age to play characters over extended timelines. He tackles the hard stuff confidently; you can feel his angst as Udham narrates the 1919 massacre, over visuals that show him as a young boy. Nevertheless, the sheer responsibility of the role seems to burden the actor. He shines in the unexpected bits, picking up a laddoo delightedly or confessing surprise with: "Tussi jante ho?""

The storytelling in this movie is non-linear. It means they did not tell us the story in the actual sequence of the events rather they started by showing us the aftermath of the Jaliyan wala bagh massacre and through flashbacks showed the incidents which took place before the massacre. They showed the Massacre scene in the last. The story has developed very well throughout the whole movie but the speed of the movie is very slow. The visuals of this movie is of very high quality, comparable to the Hollywood movies. Oppressed India and old London has been portrayed very well in this movie. The visuals in the last massacre scene is on another level. The bgm used in this movie gave each scene more depth ,intensity and thrill and worked so well all together. But the problem with this movie , as per my point view, is the lack of intense acting and dramatic scenes. It lacks imaginative scenes and dialogues. It portrayed the incidents as it is and added no masala to it. If it was a documentary, then it's ok. But as it is a big-screen movie, little spicy drama is expected. There are not lot of impressive acting scene excluding the court room scene and massacre scene in the end. All over this movie deserve a high rating because of its compelling storytelling, impressive visuals , great direction and top-notch background score. But this movie is not for all kinds of audience because most of the lines are in British English and patience is needed to go through the storyline of the movie and slowly understanding every scene. Inspite of being patriotic, this movie does not contain any high level fighting scene and will not create any josh in you. It is emotional movie in the end to make us feel what our ancestors went through to give us freedom so that we don't use it in vain.

reviews.review_title: Movie Of Indian, By Indian, For Indian
reviews.content: Another masterpiece by Shoojit Sarcar! It capture real heroic aspects of Udham Singh and portrays in nice non-linear narration. How he could he hold his anger for 21 long years and then take his revenge is telling of Indian Civilization itself. It lies low for thousand years, but refuses to forget, refuses to give up. Elephantine memory, to quote from the movie. It is slightly difficult for other cultures to appreciate this movie (probably that is the reason for not being selected for Oscar). The Jalianawallah Bagh may appear too long. But, it should be seen, frame by frame, without skipping and all the pain should be absorbed to understand. 1919 incident was watershed moment in Indian history. Best picturaization was from Richard Attenborough's Gandhi. Indian versions lacked imagination, resources or both.If we need understand Udham Singh's pursuit of 21 long year pursuit, and his decision to make it sign of protest against imperialism rather than of personal revenge, we need to patiently go through Jalianawallah Bagh scene. Yes, it does not provide any extra information, but conditions the heart.Though it does not contain against British culture per se (rather you do develop admiration for their structured governance), the pain, the anguish the sheer humiliation can be felt only by an Indian heart. Hence it is strongly recommended for every Indian.

Seldom comes a cinema so deeply engrossing, the latest directional venture by Shoojit Sircar is the finest tribute to the life of Sardar Udham Singh. This multilayered and heart wrenching film is easily one of the best movie of this decade. The movie works in multiple parallel story lines, and it has been skilfully intertwined with the final act. It starts at a slow pace, putting the characters at its locations and giving the audience a chance to feel the same emotion and frustration young Udham was feeling. Shoojit Sircar lets the audience connect to this journey, without spoon feeding the gravitas of the circumstances. The circumstances are itself powerful and patiently directed. Thanks to the mesmerising cinematography. The color palettes and set design transports the audience into the WW1 era. It speaks volumes about the hard-work and dedication the technical team has gone through to recreate that bygone era. The background score by Shantanu Moitra was cherry on the cake. The music was used so subtly that it never overpowered the essence of the act, but in a way dissolved in the anger and pain of Sardar Udham. The theme music named " Time to meet my friend" which was played in a couple of scenes was extremely heartbreaking. And finally the acting. Vicky Kaushal is magnetic in this movie. His eyes did most of the acting. What a great actor he is! Outstanding! He truly engulfed the soul of Udham Singh, with his extremely resilient yet powerful performance. His desperation, his laughs, his anger was naturally moulded in this movie. It is without any doubt his best performance, even surpassing his acting in Masaan. The British actors are meticulously selected and each one of their performance needs a mention. Shaun Scott as Michael O'Dwyer is brilliant. His dialogue delivery was top notch, making this version of Dwyer believable. Stephen Hogan did a commendable job. The acting was on flow and natural as if real investigation was being carried out. Kirsty Averton's role is minimal. I wished to see her more in other movies.As the film moves to the last 40 min, the movie sets on a roller coaster. The scenes were deeply emotional and tragic. Perhaps such kind of portrayal of Jallianwala Bagh massacre was never filmed in Indian cinema. Shoojit Sircar didn't cuts the scenes. He lets us to fully take on to the upheaval. As the movie close to end, I was devastated. I was numb to the core realising the actual pain and trauma those people had witnessed on that fateful day. Watch Sardar Udham, not just for its history, but for its near perfect execution on screen and to witness the greatness of Ram Mohammad Singh Azad.This movie will surely take away multiple awards in its bag. This is the film of this year and will find itself in the list of best International movies of 2021. Go, experience this art yourself.
